text:
What kind of format is this and what does it mean:

```function myfilter(A, kernel, ::Replicate)
    ...
end```
Can someone please explain what `::Replicate`  means here?

elements.text: What kind of format is this and what does it mean:

text: `::Replicate` indicates here a positional argument of type `Replicate`, but which doesn't have a name, so won't be used in the body of the function. It might as well have been written as `unused::Replicate`.

elements.text: indicates here a positional argument of type
, but which doesn't have a name, so won't be used in the body of the function. It might as well have been written as

text: Thanks. Is there any documentation to read more on this kind of usage/behavior?

elements.text: Thanks. Is there any documentation to read more on this kind of usage/behavior?

text: This is usually something that is used for dispatch purposes.

elements.text: This is usually something that is used for dispatch purposes.

text: I don't think there is a unified description of this pattern anywhere. It is mostly use to remove branches at compile time using type inference and dispatch. This blog post (especially the part about traits) may help you getting a grasp of the idea <https://www.oxinabox.net/2018/10/03/Dispatch,-Traits-and-Metaprogramming-Over-Reflection.html>

elements.text: I don't think there is a unified description of this pattern anywhere. It is mostly use to remove branches at compile time using type inference and dispatch. This blog post (especially the part about traits) may help you getting a grasp of the idea

text: One use of this pattern is when dispatching on singleton types, e.g. `::Nothing`, where you don't need to give name to the argument, and it's actually clearer to use `nothing` in the body of the function (if needed).
